excerpt.rendered: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

content.rendered:
The next major evolution of the web is here. Immersive content changes everything. It’s a new way to experience, a new way to learn, and a new way to consume content.

The difference is Six Degrees of Freedom or 6DoF, where you are inside of an experience in VR or able to walk around holographic images projected onto your environment in AR. Using JavaScript, web developers can create experiences in WebXR and distribute them over the web directly into headsets.

This site celebrates WebXR and promotes its adoption.

_thumbnail_id.title: WebXRLogo
_thumbnail_id.desc:
The next major evolution of the web is here. Immersive content changes everything. It's a new way to experience, a new way to learn, and a new way to consume content.

The difference is Six Degrees of Freedom or 6DoF, where you are inside of an experience in VR or able to walk around holographic images projected onto your environment in AR. Using JavaScript, web developers can create experiences in WebXR and distribute them over the web directly into headsets.

This site celebrates WebXR and promotes its adoption.

content.rendered: Until now, immersive content was the province of gaming engines, and experiences could only be created in Unity (C#) and UnReal engine (C++) and deliver them through platform-specific app stores. WebXR allows the distribution of immersive content built in JavaScript, hosted on a website and delivered to a web browser via URL without the need for game engine licenses. The WebXR Device API specification is an open standard by the W3C, that ships in Chromium, the foundation of most major browsers including Chrome, Opera and Edge for desktop and mobile, and in stereoscopic browsers Oculus for VR, Magic Leap’s Helio Browser and Nreal’s Nebula for AR.

content.rendered: Firefox Reality is an immersive browser that runs on, Viveport, Oculus Quest and Go, Pico, and a Standlone AR version for Hololens. On August 12, 2020 Mozilla disbanded most of its mixed reality team. Since then, the fate of the Firefox Reality Browser is uncertain.

title.rendered: WebXR Standards and Accessibility Architecture Issues

content.rendered: An excellent primer on understanding WebXR itself, but also as it relates to accessibility.

transform-style: detached is a proposed attribute that can separate a div on the z-access from the plane of a web-page viewed on a stereoscopic device. It has been proposed to the W3C but is not seen progress. If you have the power to lobby for this, detached CSS needs a champion for Chromium and Firefox.

content.rendered: Chromium is an open-source browser project that is the foundation of the Oculus Browser, as all versions of Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Opera, Brave and Samsung Internet Browsers. WebXR updates have been shipping with Chromium since Version 79.

categories.description: This is a curated collection of WebXR sites, each bring their own unique advancements to demonstrate the potential of the medium.
categories.name: Case Studies

categories.description: Standards established by governing bodes determine how different devices behave the same given input. The W3C Immersive Web Working Group determines the standard for WebXR. The Khronos group defines other standards which WebXR uses.
categories.name: Standards
